title: Groundhog
text:
Introduction
This project draws its data from the GitHub repository TidyTuesday’s 2024-01-30 folder titled “Groundhog Predictions”. This data is originally from https://groundhog-day.com/. This data puts together the predictions of groundhogs for 6 more weeks of winter or the coming of spring across the US and Canada.

shadow_prediction  <- predictions |>
  group_by(year) |>
  summarize(total_shadow_count = sum(shadow, na.rm = TRUE))
shadow_prediction

# A tibble: 138 × 2
    year total_shadow_count
   <dbl>              <int>
 1  1886                  0
 2  1887                  1
 3  1888                  1
 4  1889                  0
 5  1890                  0
 6  1891                  0
 7  1892                  0
 8  1893                  0
 9  1894                  0
10  1895                  0
# ℹ 128 more rows

ggplot(shadow_prediction, aes(x = year, y = total_shadow_count)) +
  geom_col()








Graphing and Code

id_prediction  <- predictions |>
  group_by(id) |>
  summarize(total_shadow_count = sum(shadow, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(id_prediction,  aes(x = id, y = total_shadow_count)) +
  geom_col() +
  labs(
    title = "Longer winter predictions per Ground Hog",
    x = "Groundhog identification",
    y = "Saw Shadow Count"
  )







ggplot(predictions, aes(x = year, fill = shadow)) +
  geom_bar() +
  labs(
    title = "Yearly Shadow Predictions",
    x = "Year",
    y = "Total Predictions"
  )








Analysis
The first graph isolates the total count of observed shadows by year. Similarly, the third graph reiterates this idea by presenting the count of all shadow predictions per year. From these graphs, it is obvious that there is a growing number of predictions by different groundhogs. The growth in groundhog day popularity is especially visible when we view the third graph in conjunction with the second graph showing the consistency and recency in groundhog count of predictions. In the second graph, we can see that earlier groundhogs have had a greater impact on the data for winter predictions.

title: Simpsons
text:
Introduction
In this project, I will use data from the TidyTuesday folder for February 2, 2025. The original data is from https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/prashant111/the-simpsons-dataset, which is a kraggle data set authored by Prashant Banerjee. This data is further scraped by other users. The data is split into four data frames of characters, episodes, locations, and script lines. I focused on script line count among the characters with the over 2000 cumulative word counts.
Graph and Code

known_character <- simpsons_script_lines |>
  group_by(character_id) |>
  summarize(total_word_count = sum(word_count, na.rm = TRUE)) |>
  filter(total_word_count > 2000)
known_character

# A tibble: 16 × 2
   character_id total_word_count
          <dbl>            <dbl>
 1            1            23903
 2            2            52649
 3            3             5023
 4            8            22528
 5            9            21675
 6           11             4319
 7           15             6841
 8           17             8773
 9           25             4075
10           31             4815
11           71             3962
12          101             2067
13          139             3857
14          165             2944
15          211             2271
16         1078             2533

known_character|>
  ggplot(aes(x = character_id, y = total_word_count)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    title = "Characters with the Highest Word Count",
    x = "Character Identification",
    y = "Total Word Count"
  )








Analysis
For this data, we can see that the characters that have said over 2000 words is limited to 16 characters. Characters that appear earlier in the character id line seem to be prominent to appear as prolific characters. The next step in this data is to identify a match between character id to character name across data frames to better understand which characters are favored for lines. If we were to exclude the main Simpson family, which characters would receive the most attention?

title: Federalist Papers Analysis
text:
Introduction
This is project 2 which seeks to work with string and character data. The data used comes from nicholasjhorton’s GitHub repository which provides a data frame for the Federalist papers.
Establishing a Government
Since the purpose of the Federalist Papers is to defend the Constitution that establishes the U.S government branches, I proceeded to examine how many times this purpose is linked through mentions of the words “government”. I provided an alternative “confederacy” due to its predecessor, the Articles of Confederation, as a name for government in reference to the United States.

Country_FedPapers <- FederalistPapers |>
  mutate(Country_FedPapers = str_to_lower(text))|>
  group_by(paper) |>
  summarise(Word_count = sum(str_count(text,"government") + 
              str_count(text,"confederacy"))) 

Although counting the occurrence of the two words does not give any context to what direction the author intends to take the paper, the repetition of the words provides a hint.
Graphing Count of “Government” and “Confederacy”

ggplot(Country_FedPapers, aes(x = paper, y = Word_count)) +
  geom_col() + 
  labs(
    x = "Federalist Paper Number",
    y = "Word Count", 
    title = "Number of times 'confederacy' or 'government' mentioned"
  )








From the graph, we can see a consistent call upon government and confederacy with the highest count being around paper 45 which describes the power of the government relative to state governments, so it is possible the constant mention of the two forms of government caused the spike.
Title Length per Paper
Another alteration to the data I will apply is separating the title into its generic FEDERALIST No. and its assigned title. From here I analyze the length of each title.

Neater_Fedpaper <- FederalistPapers |>
  mutate(solo_title = str_extract(title,"(?<=\\. ).+")) |>
  group_by(paper) |>
  summarize(title_length = str_length(first(solo_title)))

Graph of Title Length vs Specific Word Count
Then will the length of the title tell anything about the wordiness of the author? In other words, will the length of the title predict the amount of times the words confederacy and government appear?

Joined_Fedpaper <- left_join(Country_FedPapers, Neater_Fedpaper)

Joining with `by = join_by(paper)`

ggplot(Joined_Fedpaper, aes( x = title_length , y = Word_count)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(
    x = "Length of Title",
    y = "Count of government and confederacy",
    title = "Does title length predict utterances of government?"
  )








There is no easily visible marked trend. A longer title does not relate to a longer string of confederacies and government mentions that may appear in longer papers.
Constitution and What Else?
In an attempt to contextualize what is referred to as the Constitution in the Federalist papers, the following code draws out the words following the word constitution.

FederalistPapers |>
  filter(str_detect(text, "(?i)constitution"))|>
  group_by(paper)|>
  summarize(surr_const = str_c(unlist(
    str_extract_all(text, "(?i)constitution\\s+(\\w+)")), collapse = ", "))  

# A tibble: 77 × 2
   paper surr_const                                                            
   <dbl> <chr>                                                                 
 1     1 "Constitution for, CONSTITUTION TO, CONSTITUTION and, Constitution or"
 2     6 ""                                                                    
 3     7 ""                                                                    
 4     8 "constitution that"                                                   
 5     9 "constitution that"                                                   
 6    10 "Constitution forms"                                                  
 7    14 "Constitution From, Constitution are, Constitution is"                
 8    15 "constitution of"                                                     
 9    16 "Constitution which, constitution in"                                 
10    17 ""                                                                    
# ℹ 67 more rows


Althought the code does not give much context as the words following the mention of constitution are largely filler words, it does highlight the different instances of constitution. The capitalized Constitution is likely a direct reference to the U.S. Constitution. The completely capitalized CONSTITUTION is likely referenced in an address to the reader or some outstanding instance while the completely lowercase constitution is the general constitute of something.
Who Wrote the Most?
From a brief look at the authorship of each paper, it can be seen that Hamilton took authorship of most, but how many words did they write across their papers?

 FederalistPapers |>
  group_by(author) |>
  summarize(total_words = sum(str_count(text, "\\S+")))

# A tibble: 3 × 2
  author   total_words
  <chr>          <int>
1 Hamilton      114076
2 Jay             8513
3 Madison        69377


Unsurprisingly, Hamilton wrote like he was running out of time and ended with 114,076 words across his many authored papers.
